chapter.title: Data at Rest Encryption
chapter.para: The data at rest encryption features in &product; include the Barbican key management service for safely storing encryption keys, and Cinder volume encryption. This topic explains how to configure a back end for Barbican key storage, and how to configure Cinder volumes to be encrypted.
The Barbican service in &product; supports two types of back ends for safely storing encryption keys:

para.emphasis: Configuring the key management back-end key store

chapter.para: Using the &clm; reconfigure playbook, you can configure one of two back ends for the Barbican key management service:

listitem.para: Native database: This is the default configuration in &product;.

KMIP + Atalla ESKM: For a KMIP device, an SSL client certificate is needed as HSM devices generally require two-way SSL for security reasons. You will need a client certificate, a client private key and client root certificate authority recognized by your HSM device.

To configure KMIP + Atalla ESKM in place of the default database, begin by providing certificate information by modifying the sample configuration file, barbican_kmip_plugin_config_sample.yml, on the &clm; node:
Copy this file to a temporary directory such as /tmp.
Edit the file to provide either client certificates as absolute file paths as shown below in bold, or by pasting certificate and key content directly into the file.

note.para: File paths take precedence over content variables if both are provided.

listitem.para: To set file path variables, open kmip_plugin_certs.yml for editing and setting the paths to the cert files:
listitem.screen: vi /tmp/kmip_plugin_certs.yml # File paths takes precedence over cert content if both are provided. # Here file path refers to local filesystem path where ansible is # executed. client_cert_file_path: /path/to/cert/file client_key_file_path: /path/to/key/file client_cacert_file_path: /path/to/cacert/file

listitem.para: Alternatively, set the content variables by opening /tmp/kmip_plugin_certs.yml and copy the certificates and keys directly into the file.

listitem.para: Provide certificate information to the Barbican service using the barbican-reconfigure.yml playbook:
Provide HSM connection credentials for the Barbican service. In this step, provide the KMIP plug-in connection details to the Barbican service: Open the file barbican_deploy_config.yml found here:
Set the value of use_kmip_secretstore_plugin to True to use the KMIP plug-in or False to use the default secret store plugin (store_crypto).
Next, add KMIP client connection credentials and KMIP server hostname and port to barbican_deploy_config.yml:
listitem.screen: ####################################################################### #################### KMIP Plugin Configuration Section ################ ####################################################################### # Flag to reflect whether KMIP plugin is to be used as back end for #storing secrets use_kmip_secretstore_plugin: True # Note: Connection username needs to match with 'Common Name' provided # in client cert request (CSR). barbican_kmip_username: userName barbican_kmip_password: password barbican_kmip_port: 1234 barbican_kmip_host: 111.222.333.444
cd ~/openstack/ardana/ansible git add -A git commit -m "My config"
listitem.para: and run the barbican-reconfigure.yml playbook in the deployment area:
listitem.screen: ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost ready-deployment.yml cd ~/scratch/ansible/next/ardana/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts barbican-reconfigure.yml

section.title: Configuring Cinder volumes for encryption
section.para: The data-at-rest encryption model in &productname; provides support for encrypting Cinder volumes (Volume Encryption). These encrypted volumes are protected with an encryption key that can be stored in an HSM appliance.

Assuming Barbican and Cinder services have been installed, you can configure a Cinder volume type for encryption. Doing so will create a new Cinder volume type, "LUKS," that can be selected when creating a new volume. Such volumes will be encrypted using a 256bit AES key:
You should now be able to create a new volume with the type LUKS, which will request a new key from Barbican. Once created, you can attach the new volume to an instance:
The volume list (cinder show with the volume ID) should now show that you have a new volume and that it is encrypted.
